tutorialBundle.name: Whats New in 3.2
tutorialBundle.welcome:
You’re now running Android Studio 3.2. Learn more about what’s included in this update below. You can also read the full release notes in a browser or watch a video overview on YouTube.

Support for Dynamic Apps

Dynamic Apps is an easier way to update and deploy your app to an ever-growing ecosystem of diverse Android devices. With Dynamic Apps, you need to build and upload only a single build artifact, the Android App Bundle, and the Google Play Store builds, signs, and manages APKs for all device configurations you want to support.

To learn more, complete the tutorials at the bottom of this panel or read the documentation in a browser.

Navigation Editor

The Navigation Editor lets you visualize and edit navigation behavior between different components and activities in your app, so you can better assess whether navigation flows are correct and easy for users to understand. Learn more.

New Battery Profiler

Android Profilers now includes a Battery Profiler to help you assess the energy consumption of your app. The profiler visualizes your apps battery usage and allows you to inspect which device components—such as network radios or the CPU—are consuming the most energy.

New Code and Resource Shrinker

R8 is a new tool for code/resource shrinking and obfuscation that works with multi-APK apps, such as Dynamic Apps and Android Instant Apps. It replaces ProGuard, and you can start using the preview version of R8 by including the following in your project’s gradle.properties file:
android.enableR8 = true

Dynamic Apps is an easier way to update and deploy your app to an ever-growing ecosystem of diverse Android devices. With Dynamic Apps, you need to build and upload only a single build artifact, the Android App Bundle, to support all target device configurations.
